title: 108_s2934
content: The Act titled "Combating Methamphetamine Act of 2004" includes findings related to methamphetamine. Congress finds that methamphetamine is a highly addictive drug linked to violent crimes, environmental damage from lab chemicals, and has received federal funding for addressing since 2001. Federal funding for methamphetamine enforcement and clean-up has been decreasing since 2002, despite the growing problem across the United States. Each State needs more support to combat methamphetamine abuse, and permanent funding is crucial for law enforcement efforts to reduce crime rates associated with the drug. The Federal Government needs to establish a long-term commitment to combating methamphetamine use by creating a permanent funding mechanism to assist States. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to combat the use of methamphetamine by granting authority to address public safety and methamphetamine manufacturing, sale, and use. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to grant authority to States to address the manufacture, sale, and use of methamphetamine drugs, enhancing public safety through programs and projects. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to grant States authority to address methamphetamine-related issues, including arrests, lab seizures, community education, family support, intervention, treatment, Drug Court services, and community policing. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to grant States authority to address methamphetamine-related issues, including support for State and local health departments, prosecution of violations related to methamphetamine, and procurement of equipment to reduce methamphetamine use, sale, and manufacture. States must submit assurances to the Attorney General to be eligible for grants under this part. States must have laws, policies, and programs in place to restrict the sale of products used in making methamphetamine to be eligible for grants under this section. "SEC. 2992. APPLICATIONS." No grant can be approved under this part without an application submitted to and approved by the Attorney General. The application must adhere to the regulations set by the Attorney General and include a long-term statewide strategy involving consultation with various agencies and community groups, as well as addressing the issues related to methamphetamine use, manufacture, and sale. The curr_chunk outlines various components of a program related to addressing methamphetamine issues, including arrest, training, intervention, treatment, drug court, health department support, prosecution, and evaluation. The program aims to establish best practices for addressing methamphetamine issues, involving governmental and community initiatives, coordinating with relevant institutions, and incorporating Tribal participation when impacted by methamphetamine activities. The State must certify sharing funds with local governments to address methamphetamine issues, assess the impact on the criminal justice system, explain grant utilization, demonstrate public safety need, show inability to address without Federal assistance, and specify plans for ongoing support. The State must certify that funds received under this part will supplement, not supplant, other Federal, State, and local funds. SEC. 2993. PLANNING GRANTS. The Attorney General may provide grants to eligible entities to develop a strategy addressing methamphetamine issues for public safety, with a maximum grant of $100,000 per entity. This includes defining the problem, involving public and private organizations, and outlining their participation in a comprehensive approach. The Attorney General may provide grants to eligible entities to develop a strategy addressing methamphetamine issues for public safety, with a maximum grant of $100,000 per entity. Entities are expected to participate in a comprehensive, cooperative, and integrated plan to address the use, manufacture, or sale of methamphetamine. SEC. 2994 outlines the allocation of enforcement grants to States based on population ratios. SEC. 2995 pertains to national activities. The Attorney General is authorized to collect data on the effectiveness of programs in reducing methamphetamine use, establish a national clearinghouse of information on effective programs, and disseminate research results and information on best practices to address methamphetamine-related issues. The bill aims to address family problems caused by methamphetamine use through intervention, treatment, and drug courts. It also seeks to establish a program for sharing best practices among states and provide technical assistance to reduce methamphetamine use. The bill authorizes funding for combating methamphetamine use, with $100,000,000 allocated for fiscal years 2005 and 2006, and $200,000,000 for fiscal years 2007-2009. Additionally, funds are authorized for national activities as needed.
